mGRMYx-y3.memHandModelNotes: Choose warmer caves and mines usually located <1-2 km from rivers or other open bodies of water (Decher & Choate 1995). Summer caves are nearly always located within 1 km of a river or reservoir over which the bats forage (Tuttle 1979). ****Ecosystem Classifiers: Since we do not have a geology layer for the south I choose all systems with an underlying substrate of limestone or calcarous bedrock (as identified through the natureserve definitions). Also choose open water and bottomland hardwoods for foraging. Amy Silvano 10jun09 If geology layer is developed, it would take precedence by modeling within limestone regions. Amy Silvano 10jun09

mGRMYx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Choose warmer caves and mines usually located <1-2 km from rivers or other open bodies of water (Decher & Choate 1995). Summer caves are nearly always located within 1 km of a river or reservoir over which the bats forage (Tuttle 1979). ****Ecosystem Classifiers: Since we do not have a geology layer for the south I choose all systems with an underlying substrate of limestone or calcarous bedrock (as identified through the natureserve definitions). Also choose open water and bottomland hardwoods for foraging. Amy Silvano 10jun09 If geology layer is developed, it would take precedence by modeling within limestone regions. Amy Silvano 10jun09

references: Sasse, D. B., Clawson, R. L., Harvey, M. J., and S. L. Hensley. 2007. Status of populations of the endangered gray bat in the western portion of its range. Southeastern Naturalist 6(1):165-172.
Hamilton, William J., Jr., and John O. Whitaker, Jr. 1979. Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 346 pp.
Herkert, J. R., editor. 1992. Endangered and threatened species of Illinois:status and distribution. Vol. 2:Animals. Illinois Endangered Species Protection Board. iv + 142 pp.

Handley, C. O., Jr. 1991. Mammals. Pages 539-616 in K. Terwilliger, coordinator. Virginia's endangered species:proceedings of a symposium. McDonald and Woodward Publishing Company, Blacksburg, Virginia.
Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.
Figg, D. E. 1993. Missouri Department of Conservation wildlife diversity report, July 1992-June 1993. 75 pp.
Trani, M. K., W. M. Ford, and B. R. Chapman (eds.) 2007. The Land Manager's Guide to Mammals of the South. The Nature Conservancy, Southeastern Region, Durham, NC, USA. 546 pp.
Brack, V., Jr., R. E. Mumford, and V. R. Holmes. 1984. The gray bat (Myotis grisescens) in Indiana. American Midland Naturalist 111:205.
Schwartz, Charles W., and Elizabeth R. Schwartz. 1981. The Wild mammals of Missouri (2nd Ed.). Univ. of Missouri Press and Missouri Conserv. Dept., Columbia, MO. 356 p.
Decher, J., and J. R. Choate. 1995. Myotis griescens. Mammalian Species (510):1-7. Am. Soc. Mammal., New York.
Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
Ransome, R. 1990. The natural history of hibernating bats. Christopher Helm, London. xxi + 235 pp.

Tuttle, M. D. 1975. Population ecology of the gray bat (Myotis grisescens):factors influencing early growth and development. University of Kansas Museum of Natural History Occasional Papers (36):1-24.
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS). 1990. Endangered and threatened species recovery program:report to Congress. 406 pp.
Tuttle, M. D. 1979. Status, causes of decline, and management of endangered gray bats. Journal of Wildlife Management 43:1-17.
Figg, D.E. 1991. Missouri Department of Conservation annual nongame and endangered species report July 1990 - June 1991. ii + 35 pp.

Tuttle, M. D. 1976. Population ecology of the gray bat (Myotis grisescens):philopatry, timing, and patterns of movement, weight loss during migration, and seasonal adaptive strategies. University of Kansas Museum of Natural History Occasional Papers (54):
Barbour, R. W., and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. The University of Kentucky Press, Lexington, Kentucky.
Layne, J. N., editor. 1978. Rare and endangered biota of Florida. Vol. 1. Mammals. State of Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission. xx + 52 pp.
Hall, J. S., and N. Wilson. 1966. Season population movements of the gray bat in the Kentucky area. American Midlands Naturalist 75:317-24.
Gore, J. A., Lazure, L, and M. E. Ludlow. 2012. Decline in the Winter Population of Gray Bats (Myotis grisescens) in Florida. Southeastern Naturalist. 11(1):89-98.
Lacki, M. J., L. S. Burford, and J. O. Whitaker, Jr. 1995. Food habits of gray bats in Kentucky. Journal of Mammalogy 76:1256-1259.
Sherman, A.R., and C. O. Martin. 2006. Rediscovery of the gray bat (Myotis grisescens) in northeastern Mississippi. Southeastern Naturalist 51(3): 418-420.

Matthews, J. R., and C. J. Moseley (editors). 1990. The Official World Wildlife Fund Guide to Endangered Species of North America. Volume 1. Plants, Mammals. xxiii + pp 1-560 + 33 pp. appendix + 6 pp. glossary + 16 pp. index. Volume 2. Birds, Reptiles, Amphibians.
Caire, W., J. D. Tyler, B. P. Glass, and M. A. Mares. Z. Marsh (illustrator). 1989. Mammals of Oklahoma. University of Oklahoma Press, Norman. Oklahoma. 567 pp.
Brady, J., T. Kunz, M. D. Tuttle, and D. Wilson. 1982. Gray Bat Recovery Plan. U.S. Fish Wildlife Service 140 pp.
Figg, D. E., and C. M. Bessken. 1995[?]. Missouri Department of Conservation wildlife diversity report:July 1994 - June 1995. v + 104 pp. [perhaps date is 1996].
White, D. H., and J. T. Seginak. 1987. Cave gate designs for use in protecting endangered bats. Wildlife Society Bull. 15:445-449.
habitat_description:
Gray Bats (Myotis grisescens) primarily occur in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Tennessee, and Alabama (Gore et al. 2012).  They occur primarily in karst areas with underlying limestone caverns (Wilson and Ruff 1999) and choose warmer caves and mines usually located <2 km from rivers or other open bodies of water and rarely more than  4 km from water (Tuttle 1979, Decher & Choate 1995, ).  

Gray Myotis are cave dependent species, utilizing them year-round for roosting and maternity colonies (Tuttle 1979), and they are faithful to individual or clusters of caves (Trani et al. 2007).  During winter, Gray Bats congregate in a few large hibernacula, but in the summer they disperse to a larger number of caves where they form large sexually segregated groups (Sasse et al. 2007).  Movements of up to 775 km between summer and winter caves have been recorded (Trani et al. 2007).  Many roosts have presumably been flooded by the damning of rivers for reservoirs and human disturbance has driven many bats from historic roost sites (Tuttle 1979).  

This species forages primarily over open water in riparian areas and may use even the smallest of streams, but prefer broader stretches (LaVal et al. 1977).  They have large home ranges and forage over extensive areas (Sherman and Martin 2006).  In Missouri, members of one colony foraged at distancences over 20 km from the roost (USFWS 1979).  Observations of foraging Gray Bats have suggested that they remain within 5 m of the water’s surface and low above the forest canopy adjacent to water (USFWS 2007).  Movements between roosts and foraging sites occur through forest and suitable foraging sites are adjacent to forests (USFWS 1979).

 N. Tarr, 18Nov2013.
